cards

Class TitleDeed

  • java.lang.Object
    • cards.Card
      • cards.TitleDeed
  • All Implemented Interfaces:
    Printable

    public class TitleDeed
extends Card
implements Printable
    The Title Deed class describes the title deed card of a property, train station or utility site such as a Water Works. This title deed card is exactly the same as you would have in a real game of Monopoly if you owned one of these sites. It includes details such as the square's colour, the price of buying the site and what site it is linked to on the board. We decided this was a better way of presenting the CanOwn object rather than the Square itself. In terms of buying and selling, the players buy and sell these cards rather than the physical square. This is to reflect as close as possible to the real game of Monopoly where an owner holds the title deed card on their side in a game.
    Author:
    Robert Keenan and Ciaran Nolan

    • Constructor Detail

      • TitleDeed

        public TitleDeed(java.lang.String cardType,
                 java.lang.String cardTitle,
                 int cardValue,
                 java.lang.String squareColour,
                 int priceBuy,
                 int[] rents,
                 int housePrice,
                 int mortgage,
                 Player owner,
                 CanOwn ownableSite)
        The class constructor is what we use to create the title deed card and it takes a lot of arguments to the higher parent class of Card but also edits the class variables unique to the Title Deed card
        Parameters:
        cardType - This is given as a string "Title Deed"
        cardTitle - This is given as the name of the Property, Train Station or Water Works which it belongs to
        cardValue - This is set to zero as it has no value
        squareColour - This is the colour of the square. Valid for properties only
        priceBuy - The price to buy this Title Deed card's site
        rents - An array of rents depending on how many houses/hotels you have on a site or how many sites of a certain colour you own
        housePrice - The price of building a house on the site
        mortgage - The value of the mortgage for the site
        owner - A Player type which is used as the owner of this card and thus, the site
        ownableSite - The site which this Title Deed card is associated with such as a Property or Train Station

      • setBankruptcyTradeStatus

        public void setBankruptcyTradeStatus(int agreedPrice,
                                     Player recipient)
        This is used to determine the trade status of the site associated with this title deed card and whether it will be enough to make the player not bankrupt anymore. Another Player is agreed with, to provisionally receive the property.
        Parameters:
        agreedPrice - The agreed price to pay for the property by the recipient
        recipient - The Player object which is given the property if the owner achieves saving themselves from bankruptcy

      • getBankruptcyTradeStatus

        public java.util.HashMap<java.lang.Integer,Player> getBankruptcyTradeStatus()

        Returns:
        this.bankruptcyTradeStatus

      • playerAuction

        public void playerAuction(Player bankruptPlayer,
                          java.io.BufferedReader userInput)
        This is the player auction method which initiates an auction between a number of players and the owner of the title deed card (CanOwn object). It increases the bidding pool size and then a number of Player objects can go into a bidding war with each other. The auction ends when somebody enters a value to pay which all of the remaining players in the bidding war don't want to bid against by entering "n" instead of "y". If you enter a lower bid than the current highest bit, it will prompt you to enter a new bid as yours is lower than the current highest.
        Parameters:
        bankruptPlayer - The bankrupt player object who owns the property which is being auctioned off
        userInput - BufferedReader used for simulating user input for much more complex tests in JUnit
